description: September 14, 2020: With Bulletin N. 262, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended the 70th session of the WHO Regional Committee for Europe (RC70), organised by the WHO Regional Office for Europe, on September 14 and 15, 2020. Representatives of 53 countries in the WHO European Region have attended. Representatives of WHO partners such as United Nations agencies and other intergovernmental organisations and regional networks, were also present. Non-State actors (NSAs) in official relations with WHO and regional NSAs accredited by the Regional Committee, have followed the webstream and had the opportunity to submit video and written statements in advance. The key health issues and future plans have been discussed, particularly on themes regarding the response to the COVID-19 pandemic and lessons learned from the pandemic, both globally and regionally.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Cooperation among different jurisdictional entities (e.g. treaties or agreements among countries or provinces)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Greece is creating a communications' campaign to inform all citizens of the dangerous nature of COVID, raise awareness and prevent disinformation. The proliferation of such information will happen through traditional press (radio and TV), but also in a list of online websites. The measure gets in effect on 20 March 2020 and until 31 May 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 4, 2020, Greece’s Health authorities announced preventive emergency measures against the coronavirus for the prefectures of Achaia and Ilia, in Peloponnese, as well as for the island of Zakynthos. description: By order of the Deputy Minister of Civil Protection and Crisis Management, Nikos Hardalias and decision of the General Secretary of Civil Protection, Vasilios Papageorgiou, the Dept. of Malesina is declared in a Civil Protection Emergency by Sunday 28-02-2021 at 06:00 until Monday 08-03-2021 at 06:00 for Public Health reasons. It is decided: The suspension of the in-person educational operation of primary and secondary education school units (kindergartens, primary schools, all-day schools, gymnasiums and lyceums of general and vocational education), as well as all other educational structures (except special education schools). Courses will be conducted through distance learning (tele-education).

Greece’s Education Minister Niki Kerameos announced on Wednesday April 7, 2021 that students of the last three high school grades – lyceums, grades 10-12 – will return to classrooms as of Monday, April 12, 2021. 

Teachers and students will have to take Covid-19 self-tests twice a week before attending class, Thursdays and Mondays. They have to enter the results on the online platform self-testing.gov.gr, which is already partly operational.

description: On 17th March, 2020, the Ministry of immigration and Asylum announced that there will be a restriction of the traffic of those who live in KYT with a validity period of 30 days, starting 18th March, 2020. The transition of those living in the KYT to the urban centers to meet their needs will be controlled. Specifically, it will be possible to go every hour to limited groups of people in neighboring urban centers between 7 in the morning and 7 in the evening. Groups of these individuals will consist of only one member per family. The coordination and control of the above traffic of those who live in KYT, will be carried out with the care of the Greek Police, while their transition will be done only with the exclusive use of means of public transport of controlled and limited traffic.

description:
The Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) of Greece for the purposes of preventing the spread of COVID-19, announced a temporary ban on flights from the Netherlands to Greece and vice versa.
Specifically, from Sunday, March 29, 2020, at 06:00 in the morning until Holy Wednesday, April 15, 2020, at 06:00 in the morning, all passenger flights to and from the airports of these countries are suspended. 
As with the previous NOTAMS issued by the CAA, the temporary suspension of flights excludes cargo flights, sanitary flights, humanitarian flights, return flights with only its crew (ferry) flights, state flights, emergency flights, military flights, Frontex flights, refueling flights, our National Health System support flights and repatriation flights of Greek citizens.

description: From 19 May 2020 until the 15th of June by the enforcement of the Greek Government, the temporary suspension of flights for the carriage of passengers to Athens and Thessaloniki from 29 countries imposed as precautionary protection of public health due to the COVID-19 pandemic has been lifted. The list of countries concerned was drawn up, after a study of their epidemiological profile and taking into account the communications of the European Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) as well as the relevant recommendation of the Hellenic Committee of Infectious Diseases. The list of countries is as follows: Albania, Australia, Austria, North Macedonia, Bulgaria, Germany, Denmark, Switzerland, Estonia, Japan, Israel, China, Croatia, Cyprus, Latvia, Lebanon, Lithuania, Malta, Montenegro, New Zealand, Norway, South Korea, Hungary, Romania, Serbia, Slovakia, Slovenia, Czech Republic, Finland.    Visitors from the above countries will be subject to random checking for Covid-19s.    Existing rules remain in place for all other countries.    The list will be expanded on July 1. In any case, epidemiological monitoring and evaluation will be continuous.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The list of countries that have been "opening the borders" for tourists from June 15 until June 19, with flights to Athens and Thessaloniki, is announced.    The list of 29 countries was formed after a study of the epidemiological profile of the countries of origin of tourists and after taking into account yesterday's announcements of the European Air Safety Agency (EASA), as well as the relevant recommendation of the Infectious Diseases Committee.    Visitors from the following countries will be sampled.    The existing rules still apply to all other countries.    The list, which will be expanded starting on July 1, will be announced in time. In any case, epidemiological monitoring and evaluation will be ongoing.     In detail, the list of countries is as follows:     Albania, Australia, Austria, Northern Macedonia, Bulgaria, Germany, Denmark, Switzerland, Estonia, Japan, Israel, China, Croatia, Cyprus, Latvia, Lebanon, Lithuania, Malta, Montenegro, Romania, New Zealand, Norway, Serbia, Slovakia, Slovenia, Czech Republic, Finland.

description: On June 15 by the enforcement of the Greek Government, the practice of mandatory testing and quarantine will continue to be performed for passengers coming from countries at high risk of transmitting Covid-19, as assessed by the European Unions Aviation Safety Agency (EASA). ). The list is constantly updated. The following categories of passengers are excluded from the restrictions due to Covid-19: * Passengers in transit, Flight Crew, Crew of state flights, sanitary flights, humanitarian flights, emergency flights, military flights, cargo flights, and Frontex flights.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Greece announces that from June 15 to 30, 2020, if the traveler originates from an airport on the EASA affected area list, then they will be tested upon arrival. An overnight stay at a designated hotel is required. If the test is negative then the passenger self-quarantines for 7 days. If the test is positive, the passenger is quarantined under supervision for 14 days.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: By the enforcement of Greece's Government, international airports in Athens and Thessaloniki are lifting some restrictions for incoming international flights on Monday, June 15, 2020, with specific health-safety protocols in place on the ground. Specifically, as of Monday, Athens International Airport (which continued to receive international flights from specific countries during the last three months), will lift restrictions on arrivals from Italy, Spain, and The Netherlands until June 30. Flights from Albania and North Macedonia will be allowed only for essential travel of non-tourist nature, while the ban on flights from Great Britain and Turkey will be maintained, regardless of the European Union Aviation Safety Agency's (EASA) list. The Thessaloniki International Airport, after three months of restrictions, will, as of Monday too and until June 30 receive all international flights, except those from Italy, Spain, The Netherlands, Great Britain, Turkey, Albania, and North Macedonia. All other airports across the country will open to international flights on July 1.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The list of countries that have been "opening the borders" for tourists from June 15 until July 2 provided by the Greek government, with flights to Athens and Thessaloniki, is announced.    The list of 29 countries was formed after a study of the epidemiological profile of the countries of origin of tourists and after taking into account yesterday's announcements of the European Air Safety Agency (EASA), as well as the relevant recommendation of the Infectious Diseases Committee.    Visitors from the following countries will be sampled.    The existing rules still apply to all other countries.    The list, which will be expanded starting on July 1, will be announced in time. In any case, epidemiological monitoring and evaluation will be ongoing.     In detail, the list of countries is as follows:     Albania, Australia, Austria, Northern Macedonia, Bulgaria, Germany, Denmark, Switzerland, Estonia, Japan, Israel, China, Croatia, Cyprus, Latvia, Lebanon, Lithuania, Malta, Montenegro, Romania, New Zealand, Norway, Serbia, Slovakia, Slovenia, Czech Republic, Finland.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: The Greek government has introduced stricter border controls at its land borders for at least two weeks from midnight (local time) on Tuesday, July 21. Essential travel into Greece will only be permitted at the Kakavia, Krystallopigi, Evzoni, Promachonas, Nymfaia, and Kipi checkpoints. Greek citizens, those with residence permits, or holders of an Expatriate Identity Card will be required to complete a passenger locator form as well as an electronic advance notice form when crossing the border.

description: The Ministers of Health, Infrastructure and Transport, Shipping and Island Policy of Greece announced the temporary ban imposed by Greece on flights to and from Turkey to prevent the spread of COVID-19 from today 23 March 2020 at 24:00 until April 15, 2020 at 15:00. The temporary suspension of flights to and from Turkey are excluded the cargo, the sanitary, the humanitarian ), ferry flights (return of aircraft with only its crew), state (emergency), emergency (over), overflights, refueling and return flights. description: On 27th of June 2020, the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) of Greece announces to the passenger public that all passengers on international flights to Greece need to complete the Passenger Locator Form (PLF). The form has to be submitted online at least 48 hours before arriving to Greece and it will include information about the airport of departure, their address of residence, time spent in Greece and other details. This notam will be valid from Saturday 27 June 2020 until Monday 31 August 2020, UPDATE: The policy is extended to September 30 2020

description: The Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) of Greece informs the passenger public about the aviation directive (notam) concerning travelers from Russia and will be valid from Monday, September 7 until Monday, September 21, 2020 at midnight. In particular, permanent residents of Russia coming to Greece will undergo a sampling laboratory medical test for covid-19. Until the results of the laboratory test are issued, passengers will remain confined to their place of temporary residence. Also, all passengers must bring a hotel booking receipt or other appropriate documents, which indicate their place of temporary residence in Chora. UPDATE: The policy is extended until October 5 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) of Greece informs the passenger public about the aviation directive (notam) concerning travelers from Russia and will be valid from Monday, September 7 until Monday, September 21, 2020 at midnight. The aviation directive stipulates a maximum entry of 500 people per week from Russia and only at the airports of Athens, Thessaloniki and Heraklion. Persons who violate the measure of Controlled Entry of Permanent Residents of the Russian Federation and without prejudice to the prescribed criminal sanctions, an administrative fine of five thousand (5,000) euros is imposed. UPDATE: The policy is extended to October 5 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
The Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) of Greece announces a new Notam concerning passenger flight restrictions to and from Kozani "Filippos" airport, which is part of the precautionary measures against Covid-19 and is valid from October 16 until midnight on October 29 2020.The Aviation Directive provides that only departures for return flights with its crew (ferry flights) are permitted.
The following exceptions apply to flight restrictions at Kozani Airport:
* Passenger flights in transit
* Crews and passengers of the following flights: state flights, sanitary flights, humanitarian flights, emergency flights and military flights flights).
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

The aviation directive stipulates that only departures for return flights with its crew are allowed.

description: The Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) of Greece announces that from 16th September 2020 until 30th of September 2020, it is provided that those traveling to Greece by air from Belgium, Spain, Albania and Northern Macedonia will enter our country only with a negative Covid-19 test which will be performed up to 72 hours before their arrival. From this specific air directive in relation to the pre-existing one, Sweden is removed from the arrival list only with a negative test of 72 hours, but it remains the measure of taking sampling tests for covid-19 to passengers from the Scandinavian country. description: The Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) of Greece informs the passenger public about the aviation directive (notam) concerning travelers from Poland, Czech Republic and Hungary and will be valid from October 13 until October 25, 2020 at midnight. In particular, in order to limit the spread of COVID-19, it is predicted that those traveling to Greece by air connection from Russia will enter our country only with a negative Covid-19 test, which will be performed by PCR method (oral or nasopharyngeal sampling), up to 72 hours before their arrival. description: On 27th of June 2020, the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) of Greece announces to the passenger public that all passengers on international flights to Greece need to complete the Passenger Locator Form (PLF). The form has to be submitted online at least 48 hours before arriving to Greece and it will include information about the airport of departure, their address of residence, time spent in Greece and other details. This notam will be valid from Saturday 27 June 2020 until Monday 31 August 2020, UPDATE: Extended to 8 November 2020
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: The Civil Aviation Service (CAA) of Greece announces new notam regarding passenger flight restrictions from the two landing areas of light aircraft, Chortero and Emmanouil Pappas in Serres from 29 October until 6 November 2020. Flights from the landing field in Chortero, Serres and from the landing field of Serres - Emmanuel Pappas outside the regional unit of Serres are not allowed. Local training flights are excluded from the flight restrictions only within the regional unit of Serres.

description: Starting from October 30 until November 11, 2020, U.S. citizens residing in the United States are banned from entering Greece for non-essential travel, which includes tourism, unless you have an EU passport or meet one of the very narrow exceptions detailed in their posted information on entrance into the European Union/Schengen Area.  There is no projected date when entry will be permitted."   British nationals are not affected by the European Union’s measures to close EU borders to non-EU country nationals. If you’re a British national, you can still enter Greece, but you must comply with the Greek authorities’ requirements, including on testing and self-isolation.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: From 11th of November, 2020, all people traveling to Greece from foreign countries will be required to have a negative molecular test result  PCR  for COVID-19, performed up to 72 hours before their entry to Greece. This includes air and land arrivals to Greece. Travelers should be laboratory tested with RT-PCR of oropharyngeal or nasopharyngeal swab. Only travellers who carry a certificate of a negative RT-PCR test result will be allowed by the border authorities to enter the country. The certificates should be written in English and bear the name and passport national ID number of the traveller. All travellers will still have to complete and submit their PLF form and may be subject to random testing upon arrival to the Greek border
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description: From March 1, 2021, greek citizens, permanent residents of Greece, transport workers and travellers for essential professional reasons can enter Greece from border crossing points  Kakavia, Evzoni, Kipi. The border crossing points Promahonas and Kipi are open daily from 7.00 to 23.00 and Kakavia and Evzones are opened from 7.00 to 19.00. All those entering from BCPs Promahonas, Kakavia, Evzoni and Kipi should have the PLF and QR code and additionally hold a negative COVID-19 PCR test taken at most 72h prior to their arrival.

description: "US citizens residing in the United States are banned from entering Greece per details above under Entry and Exit Requirements.  All travelers entering Greece through March 8, 2021 are subject to a mandatory seven-day preventive quarantine, as announced January 8, 2021.  In addition, travelers who entered Greece from the United Kingdom must take a PCR test at the end of the quarantine period with negative results in order to be released from preventive quarantine, according to the airport website.  Travelers are advised to check with Greek authorities regarding any quarantine restrictions in effect at the time of entry into Greece.  On July 9, 2020, the Greek Ministry of Foreign Affairs posted procedures for international arrivals.  See the airport website for additional details.  If you are tested for COVID-19, you are permitted to travel to your final destination where you must self quarantine for 24 hours (or longer as described above).  If positive, you will be notified and quarantined for 14 days.  If negative, you will not be notified."
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Greece will only allow EU citizens, EU residents, and residents of certain other specific countries to enter starting from March 31 until April 12, 2021. The United States is not one of those countries.  U.S. citizens traveling to Greece will not be permitted to enter unless they meet one of only a few narrow exceptions detailed in the Greek Embassy’s information on entrance into the European Union/Schengen Area.  There is no projected date when entry will be permitted.  A long visit in a third country will not help you get around EU restrictions.  Closure of all land borders to all non-essential travel, except for the border with Bulgaria, which remains open at the Promachonas crossing point. (For the purposes of cross-border travel, the Greek authorities define essential travel as a movement by Greek citizens, permanent residents of Greece (anyone in those 2 categories who is returning to Greece), transport workers, and anyone traveling for essential professional reasons (anyone in those categories who needs to travel in either direction for professional reasons)); all arrivals by sea by private yachts, cruise ships, ferries, and any other professional tourist ships are prohibited;
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings
target_region: European Union (with the UK),Schengen Area (with the UK)

description: By the enforcement of the Greek Government, the border checkpoints of Nymfaia and Promachonas opened to tourists on April 19, 2021, following a Joint Ministerial Decision to trial tourist entry into Greece. To enter, tourists must display a negative PCR test conducted within 3 days of their attempted entry as well as undergo a rapid test administered by Greek health authorities at the border. Prior to this pilot program, the checkpoints had been shut for months, allowing only professional truck drivers to cross the borders.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description: As of Monday, April 19, 2021, until June 1, 2021, travelers from all EU member states and members of the border-free Schengen area, the United States, the United Kingdom, the United Arab Emirates, Serbia, and Israel, will be able to enter Greece without having to undergo a seven-day period of self-isolation after arrival only if:    A. you have a negative PCR test performed less than three days (72 hours) prior to arrival, This test is mandatory for all tourists (including children over the age of 5), regardless of the epidemiological situation prevalent in the country of departure.    Or    B. you have a vaccination certificate issued by a public authority in the English language, stating that 14 days have passed since the completion of your full vaccination for COVID-19.    In addition, completing a PLF form at least 24 hours prior to arrival continues to be a requirement prior to entry.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: The Greek government has announced that, from 19 April, arrivals from the UK with proof of a negative COVID-19 PCR test, undertaken within the 72-hour period before arrival into Greece are exempted from the need to self-isolate on arrival to Greece. In addition to this, they have announced that UK travelers with proof of two COVID-19 vaccinations completed at least 14 days before travel are also exempt from self-isolation (see Demonstrating your COVID-19 vaccination status). Until there is means to certify vaccinations for international travel, all travelers should continue to obtain a PCR test as stated above.    The exemption from self-isolation detailed above also applies to arrivals from the EU, United States, Serbia, Israel, and the United Arab Emirates.

description: Starting from May 18 until May 25, anyone travelling to Greece must comply with the Greek authorities’ requirements, including completion of a Passenger Locator Form (PLF) before you travel (both into and out of Greece). Read this section of the travel advice in full and check the Greek authorities’ advice to understand how these requirements apply to you.    You must wear a face mask at all times when on an aeroplane, bus, train or ferry travelling to or from Greece; and whilst at airports.    The following measures are in place with respect to travel to Greece:    Travellers must fill in a Passenger Locator Form (PLF) no later than 11.59 PM of the day before arriving in Greece. Please see below for further guidance on the Passenger Locator Form.  Arrivals from the UK must provide either; proof of a negative COVID-19 PCR test, undertaken within the 72-hour period before arrival into Greece, or proof of two COVID-19 vaccinations completed at least 14 days before travel (see Demonstrating your COVID-19 vaccination status). Travellers with proof of either are exempted from the need to self-isolate on arrival to Greece.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Starting from July 6 until July 20, UK nationals are permitted to enter Greece if they are a permanent resident in the UK, Greece, another EU/EFTA state, or in one of the following countries; Albania, Australia, Bahrain, Belarus, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Canada, China, Israel, Japan, Kuwait, Lebanon, Montenegro, New Zealand, North Macedonia, Qatar, Rwanda, Saudi Arabia, Serbia, Singapore, South Korea, Thailand, Russian Federation, United Arab Emirates, United States and Ukraine. If you’re a British national who resides in another country, not listed above, you may be refused entry to Greece due to measures put in place by the Greek authorities to combat the spread of COVID-19.  Arrivals from the UK must provide either: proof of a negative COVID-19 PCR test, undertaken within the 72 hour period before arrival into Greece; proof of a negative COVID-19 rapid antigen test from an authorised laboratory, undertaken within the 48 hour period before the scheduled flight; or proof of two COVID-19 vaccinations completed at least 14 days before travel (see Demonstrating your COVID-19 vaccination status). Travellers with proof of either are exempted from the need to self-isolate on arrival to Greece.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Starting from July 20 until August 24, 2021, additional restrictions on entry by air  Air connections with Greece are liable to suspension or amendment, sometimes at short notice. If you are due to fly to or from Greece, you should contact your airline or operator for the latest information.    Additional restrictions on entry by land borders  Greece’s land borders are subject to restrictions at present. Monitor official information from the Greek authorities on any changes to border arrangements. Arrivals must have completed a Passenger Locator Form prior to travel. You should also refer to the ‘Coronavirus’ pages for details of how local or national measures may affect travel across land borders.  To have completed a Passenger Locator Form (PLF) no later than 11:59pm (local time Greece) the day before arriving in Greece. The form is required regardless of the means of transport you use to travel to Greece (including by ferry, road, rail or air); and  Proof of a negative COVID-19 PCR test, undertaken within the 72 hour period before arrival into Greece.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description: We are therefore extending the use of this useful tool to a range of private sector activities starting from April 14 until April 19, 2021, in Greece. What are these areas? Retail, including supermarkets and food and beverage stores.The focus. Transport, land, sea, and air. Cleaning services. Barber shops, hairdressers, beauty salons, and gambling and betting services. These are the activities covered by the Joint Ministerial Decision. For the exercise of these activities, self-tests are mandatory for the arrival of employees at their workplaces and for the provision of work with a physical presence. They should be performed once a week. If the self-test is now positive, the employee should have a repeat test within 24 hours. He does not come to work. Performs a retest either in a free public structure, including those posted on the self-testing platform. gov. gr, or in a private structure of his choice. If he goes to a private structure at the expense of himself or his employer.

The cost for COVID-19 PCR tests is capped at 60 euros, and for antigen (rapid) tests at 15 euros. Patients needing COVID-19 tests or exhibiting possible symptoms may contact the COVID-19 hotline at 1135 for guidance on testing and referral for medical care. Travelers are recommended to contact testing centers in advance for appointments and not expect to be able to test and receive results the day of travel. Test results may be delivered by e-mail or in hard copy provided in person; consult with the testing facility regarding the method results are communicated for your specific circumstance. Greece, June 6th, 2020.
The Ministry of Development and Investment published hygiene rules for organized private and non-organized beaches. Sunbeds must be disinfected after each change of their rent and bathers are responsible for placing on towel on them. Sanitary facilities (WC, locker rooms, showers) must be regularly disinfected and cleaning programs must be displayed for inspection authorities. Non-compliance will result in a fine of 5,000 to 25,000 euros and suspension of operation for 15 to 20 days for each violation. These measures are valid from June 18th, 2020 to August 31st, 2020.

description:
Greece, July 3rd, 2020.
The Ministry of Tourism and Ministry for Development and Investment published health protocols regarding conducting conferences in conference centers and tourist accomodations. Before conferences, common areas and WCs must be cleaned/disenfected regularly with extra attention given to sinks, doorknobs, and other frequent points of contact. Conference rooms must be ventilated continuously with doors wide open, and trash bins must be placed both inside and outside the conference area with garbage collected at regualr intervals. During meetings,water bottles used at the chair are to be replaced and microphones must be cleaned after a change of speaker. Podium controls must be cleaned after each presentation. Alcoholic antiseptic dispensers must be placed in conspicuous places in the conference room and in public areas both indoors and outdoors, and must be regularly checked for re-supply. The premises is to be cleaned daily after the end of a conference. In WCs, toilets need to have an automatic chlorine release system that is simultaneous with flushing and there must be a washbasin with a liquid soap pump, hand towels, and a foot-operated closed waste bin.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)

description: On March 23, 2020, the government of Greece will impose a total ban on public movement as of 6 a.m. Monday to stem the spread of the novel coronavirus, Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis said Sunday in a televised address. Movement is permitted only for a prescribed set of reasons that include moving to or from the workplace during normal business hours, shopping for food or medicine, visiting a doctor or assisting a person in need of help, exercising individually or in pairs or walking a pet, attending a ceremony (wedding, baptism, funeral etc.)

description: Greece On 22 March, the Greek authorities announced significant restrictions on movements outside the home for the foreseeable future. From 6am local time on 23 March, movement outside your home or accommodation is permitted only for a prescribed set of reasons, including to visit the supermarket, pharmacy, doctor; or to go to work. Journeys by car are only permitted for these reasons, and the driver may only have one passenger in their vehicle. When requested by the Greek authorities, you will need to provide paper or digital certification of the purpose of your movement; failure to produce such certification is punishable by a fine of €150. In addition, you should also carry your I.D. card or passport when leaving your home or accommodation.

description: Greece On 22 March, the Greek authorities announced significant restrictions on movements outside the home for the foreseeable future. From 6am local time on 23 March, movement outside your home or accommodation is permitted only for a prescribed set of reasons, including to visit the supermarket, pharmacy, doctor; or to go to work. Journeys by car are only permitted for these reasons, and the driver may only have one passenger in their vehicle. When requested by the Greek authorities, you will need to provide paper or digital certification of the purpose of your movement; failure to produce such certification is punishable by a fine of €150. In addition, you should also carry your I.D. card or passport when leaving your home or accommodation. UPDATE: Hellenic Police installed permanent roadblocks and intensified checks of vehicles in all national roads and highways across the country, as well of travellers at the airports, ports, railway and bus stations. Anyone travelling by car without a valid reason to a destination other than his permanent residency is charged with a fine of 300 euros, is obliged to return to his place of origin and the vehicle registration plates are seized for 60 days
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 2, 2021, the government of Greece is enforcing that a nationwide lockdown is in effect 24 hours per day. As of March 4, 2021, the weekend curfew is expanded in Athens, Thessaloniki and other high COVID areas, in effect from 7:00pm to 5:00am. description:
The Government of Greece announced that a lockdown will be in effect from 23rd March, 2020 to 11th April, 2020.
 UPDATE: The lockdown is extended until 4th May, 2020.

The first phase of the reopening plan is to begin on May 4 when some retail stores, including bookshops and hair salons, will reopen, with others to follow suit later in the month. 

Also from May 4, citizens will no longer have to send an SMS or carry a document citing their reason for leaving their home but a ban on leaving the region where they live will remain in place. 

Cafes and restaurants will be allowed to reopen from June 1, but only with outdoor seating, as will shopping malls and year-round hotels. 

From May 4, churches will reopen for individual prayer, but with restrictions on the number of worshippers allowed inside the church, while services will be permitted to resume from May 17.  

As for schools, they are to open gradually, starting on May 11 with students of senior high
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

update_level_var: Volume of policy relaxing ; [target_direction] of policy relaxing ; [travel_mechanism] of policy relaxing ; [compliance] of policy relaxing ; [enforcer]  of policy relaxing ; timing of policy relaxing
description:
"The Government of Greece announced that a lockdown will be in effect from 23rd March, 2020 to 11th April, 2020." This was then extended until 4th May, 2020.
 UPDATE: The Greek government’s announced plan for re-opening (subject to change at any time): 
May 4:  A mask or facial cover is mandatory in public transportation, taxis, elevators, hospitals, clinics and diagnostic centers.  Masks are recommended in supermarkets, hair salons and other enclosed spaces.  Violators may be fined 150 Euros.  Movement certificates are no longer required; however, travel restrictions from one prefecture to another remain in force.  Individual outdoor exercise is permitted while organized beaches remain closed.  Certain shops are open including:  small shops, bookstores, sports stores, garden shops, consumer goods stores, flower shops, electric appliance stores, optical shops, and – by appointment only – hairdressers.
May 11:  Remaining retail stores except for malls and department stores open.
May 18:  Travel restrictions within the country will be lifted, allowing movement from one prefecture to another, except for the islands.
June 1:  Shopping malls, department stores, and hotels that operate year round open.  Restaurants and coffee shops operate only open-air premises.
Early June:  Opening of entertainment and sports venues (cinemas, theaters, entertainment centers, gyms, etc.), with social distancing and at 60% capacity.  Interior spaces of restaurants and coffee shops open.
Mid June:  Seasonal tourist accommodations open, restoration of regular sea ferry traffic to the islands.  This is when the Greek government expects to open the islands for tourism
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Greece "EOPYY and PFS Collective Agreement on Private Pharmacy Distribution Signed": As part of the implementation of the government's program to eliminate the suffering of seriously ill patients, the Collective Bargaining Agreement was signed today for the sale of high-cost drugs by private pharmacies, without any financial burden for the citizens.In the contract, EOPYY and PFS agreed for the distribution of FYK by EOPYY, with the final point of delivery being the private pharmacies, while the process of their delivery is also foreseen.The program includes oncological drugs and drugs for patients with multiple sclerosis, which do not require pre-approval by the Electronic Pre-Approval System (SIP). In total, these are 36 formulations that correspond to 85 EOF codes.

description: Greece - Restriction and regulation of businesses: On Tuesday 17 March, the government of Greece ordered a shutdown of all retailers other than chemists, supermarkets and gas stations, effective from Wednesday and lasting for at least 10 days. UPDATE: Starting from May 11, 2020, Greece enters its second phase of its gradual lifting of lockdown restrictions introduced in early March to contain the spread of the virus. All retail stores will be reopened Monday, May 11th; the use of masks is mandatory. Retailers are allowed to let up to four customers in shops of up to 20 square metres (215 square feet), four people plus one for each additional 10 square metres in premises up to 100 square metres and 12 people plus one per additional 15 square metres for premises exceeding 100 square metres. Those who enter the stores are required to maintain a 1.5-metre distance from others at all times.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Greek government announced new measures, according to which from 18 June, 2020 to 2 July, 2020, the administrations of all types of businesses, which operate beaches, must ensure that the following rules are observed. Up to 1000 sq.m. the presence of 40 people is allowed. The umbrellas should be at least 4 meters apart from each other - from axis to axis - and at least 1 meter the perimeter of their shades. Sunbeds under different umbrellas should be at least 1.5 meters apart. Up to 2 sunbeds per umbrella should be available, except in the case of families with minor children. The sunbeds must be disinfected after each change of their lease during the day. A towel must be placed on the sun lounger under the responsibility of the bather. Regular disinfection of sanitary facilities and posting of the cleaning and disinfection program that will be displayed at the control authorities is mandatory. Personal sport is allowed. Team sports that require physical contact are not allowed. As for delivery of products in a package (take away) and delivery at the exhibition point (sunbed), the products must be sold only packaged and it is forbidden to prepare them in the area except for drinks such as coffee, juices, etc. It is forbidden to broadcast music and organize events that cause consumer gathering. It is forbidden for customers to use the bars for their stay. The development of table seats in the operating room of the store is allowed.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Other Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Restriction of number of customers,Other Health Monitoring
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The government of Greece, on 16th September, 2020, announced the following restrictions for businesses in Attica and Athens: Indoor venues with live music will not be operating, wearing masks will be mandatory in all indoors work areas, offices etc., cinemas and theatres will be operating at 60% capacity and wearing masks at all times is compulsory, the number of people who can sit together at a restaurant table will now be limited to 6 people and the number of people attending events and social gatherings is still limited to 50. These restrictions are enforced intiially for a period of 14 days.

description:
The General Secretariat for Civil Protection of Greece on Tuesday, 15th September, 2020, announced that the following restrictions have been announced for the city of Trikala, which will run for a period of 14 days from September 16 until September 30.

– All public and social events and gatherings will have a 50-person cap, with the exception of activities in establishments where special rules already apply such as restaurants, theaters and cinemas

description: measures are also imposed in the Regional Unit of Kozani of the Region of Western Macedonia, from 7.10.2020 and 22:00 until 12.10.2020 to limit the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic. From 12:00 a.m. to 5:00 a.m. the following day, all retail sales of goods are prohibited from being conducted by kiosks, mini-marts (including those found inside gas stations), wineries, tobacconists, grocery stores, bakeries, and confectioneries. Pharmacies, gas stations, and vending machines are exempt from the suspension of the preceding clause, with the exception of the sale of alcoholic beverages.

Head of Greece’s Civil Protection Nikos Hardalias announced on Friday, April 9, 2021, the opening of some business activities from April 12, 2021.

Retail in Achaia with click inside and click away. Retail in Thessaloniki with click away only. Retail in other regions continues, however, with the lifting of cap 20 persons. From Monday, 1 person per 25 square meters in stores up to 500 sq meters, and one customer for every 100 sqm above 500 sqm.

description:
The Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs, on 5th July, 2021, announced that from Monday 5/7/2021 to 1/8/2021, it is mandatory for all the employees of the private sector to conduct a self-diagnostic test that is valid up to twenty-four (24) hours before the first day of the week when the employee provides his / her job with physical presence. It is reminded that the self test must be carried out once a week, before the arrival of the employee at the place of work and is valid for one (1) week from the day of its conduct.
Exceptions apply for employees who have completed atleast 14 days of vaccination for Covid-19.

description: From May 11, 2020, Greece's PPC SA proceeds with the reopening of its stores, fully following the instructions of the State for taking preventive measures to deal with the coronavirus pandemic. The stores will operate exclusively for payments, conclusion of New Contracts, and change of contract details. To protect its customers and employees, entrance to PPC stores will take place after temperature measurement of those entering the store area through special gates or temperature measurement devices; inside the stores there will be hand disinfection devices, while employees will be required to wear masks. The same is recommended to customers entering the premises. The relevant information material has already been placed in the stores. All other work will continue to be carried out by PPC's alternative service channels, namely the website www.dei.gr and the 11770 telephone center, which have upgraded the number and quality of the services they offer.

 UPDATE: According to Greek government, museums reopen on June 15, 2020 , complying with all necessary protection measures.

description: According to Greek government, museums reopen on June 15, 2020 , complying with all necessary protection measures. Special safe use protocols are applied, adapted to the specifics of each Museum, which define not only the maximum number of visitors, but also the safe routes of browsing and viewing, entrance and exit. Specifically, it is mandatory for visitors to use a non-medical mask. They must keep a distance of 1.5 m between themselves for open spaces and 2 m for closed spaces. Regarding tickets, it is recommended to use an electronic ticket, where it exists, in order to control the flow of visitors. Special provision will be made for the service of the disabled, people over 65, etc. In the event that organized guided tours are carried out, distances and special measures must be strictly observed, such as the use of a wireless guided tour. Group tours should not be more than eight people. Workers in contact with the public will use a protective non-medical mask and antiseptic.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: The Ministry of Interior on 7th November, 2020, introduced 3 different sets of working hours in the public sector during the lockdown. There will be three different shifts for employees, namely 7 a.m. to 3 p.m., 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. and 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. The possibility of special purpose leave is being reintroduced for vulnerable groups, but also for those who have children in high school. Office work will be conducted with the observance of at least 1.5 meters between employees and the continuous use of masks in all areas. The measure lasts until the end of lockdown, that is 14th December, 2020.

description: From 5 May, 2020, as announced by the Greek Ministry of Culture and Sports, the operation of the sports facilities in the country is allowed to cover the preparation and training needs of athletes of the pre-Olympic teams for the following sports: Shooting, Table Tennis, Instrumental Gymnastics, Rhythmic Gymnastics (individual), Fencing, Weightlifting, Tennis, Canoe-Kayak, Cycling , Sailing, Rowing, Athletics. Also, the operation of the open sports facilities used by the PAE teams, which participate in the professional championship of the A1 National Men's Category (Super League 1), is allowed only for individual training of their football players in small teams of six to eight people. The operation of the open facilities used by sports clubs and groups that have a legal license for tennis, golf, horse riding, shooting, archery, air sports, motor sports, underwater activity and mountain climbing, and their use by athletes and their members aged 15 and over, is allowed as well.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: From 17 May until 31 August 2020, as per national government instructions, in Greece, it is permitted to hold services, worship gatherings, liturgies, sacraments and any kind of religious ceremony, as well as the attendance of persons for individual or private prayer in all without exception the places of religious worship (of any kind and of every legal, canonical and generally religious regime of temples and chapels, houses of worship, mosques, synagogues, etc.) of every denomination and religion, regardless of their size and capacity, throughout the country only under precautionary conditions. The obligations also cover places of worship located within public, municipal, charitable, welfare or other services, shops and facilities (e.g. hospitals and psychiatric hospitals, nursing homes, boarding schools, cemeteries, camps), private estates, buildings and businesses (e.g. .e. housing complexes, event centers, hotels), Holy Monasteries, Monasteries, Hermitages and other places of abandonment within the country.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
The government of Greece, on 16th September 2020, announced the following mass gathering restrictions for Athens and all of Attica: 
- The number of people attending events and social gatherings is still limited to 50
- Outdoor concerts, performances and other similar events will be happening, but the number of people who can attend will be 50% of the usual capacity. Attendants will need to be seated and wear masks. Smoking and alcohol use will not be allowed.
- Cinemas and theatres will be operating at 60% capacity
- The number of people attending events and social gatherings is still limited to 50

Furthermore, the following restriction is in place for Trikala.
- The number of people attending events and gatherings will be limited to 50

These measures are in place until 30th September, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Starting from May 11, 2020, Greece enters its second phase of its gradual lifting of lockdown restrictions introduced in early March to contain the spread of the virus. All retail stores closed since March will be reopened Monday, May 11th; the use of masks is mandatory. Retailers are allowed to let up to four customers in shops of up to 20 square metres (215 square feet), four people plus one for each additional 10 square metres in premises up to 100 square metres and 12 people plus one per additional 15 square metres for premises exceeding 100 square metres. Those who enter the stores are required to maintain a 1.5-metre distance from others at all times.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Retail Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From May 11, 2020, Greece's PPC SA proceeds with the reopening of its stores, fully following the instructions of the State for taking preventive measures to deal with the coronavirus pandemic. The stores will operate exclusively for payments, conclusion of New Contracts, and change of contract details. To protect its customers and employees, entrance to PPC stores will take place after temperature measurement of those entering the store area through special gates or temperature measurement devices; inside the stores there will be hand disinfection devices, while employees will be required to wear masks. The same is recommended to customers entering the premises. The relevant information material has already been placed in the stores. All other work will continue to be carried out by PPC's alternative service channels, namely the website www.dei.gr and the 11770 telephone center, which have upgraded the number and quality of the services they offer.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Other government service not specified above
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On 13th May, 2020, a Joint Ministerial Decision (JMD) was issued by the Education and Religion ministry and the Health Ministry. The decision 
 was made to open all religious places with restrictions on gatherings. A maximum of 50 people will be allowed in places of worship that have an area of more than 500 square meters. Furthermore, the JMD will allow one person per 10 square metres, while congregation members must maintain a safe distance of 1.5m from each other.

description: According to Greek government, museums reopen on June 15, 2020 , complying with all necessary protection measures. Special safe use protocols are applied, adapted to the specifics of each Museum, which define not only the maximum number of visitors, but also the safe routes of browsing and viewing, entrance and exit. Specifically, it is mandatory for visitors to use a non-medical mask. They must keep a distance of 1.5 m between themselves for open spaces and 2 m for closed spaces. Regarding tickets, it is recommended to use an electronic ticket, where it exists, in order to control the flow of visitors. Special provision will be made for the service of the disabled, people over 65, etc. In the event that organized guided tours are carried out, distances and special measures must be strictly observed, such as the use of a wireless guided tour. Group tours should not be more than eight people. Workers in contact with the public will use a protective non-medical mask and antiseptic.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Public museums/galleries
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Greek government announced new measures, according to which from 18 June, 2020 to 2 July, 2020, the administrations of all types of businesses, which operate beaches, must ensure that the following rules are observed. Up to 1000 sq.m. the presence of 40 people is allowed. The umbrellas should be at least 4 meters apart from each other - from axis to axis - and at least 1 meter the perimeter of their shades. Sunbeds under different umbrellas should be at least 1.5 meters apart. Up to 2 sunbeds per umbrella should be available, except in the case of families with minor children. The sunbeds must be disinfected after each change of their lease during the day. A towel must be placed on the sun lounger under the responsibility of the bather. Regular disinfection of sanitary facilities and posting of the cleaning and disinfection program that will be displayed at the control authorities is mandatory. Personal sport is allowed. Team sports that require physical contact are not allowed. As for delivery of products in a package (take away) and delivery at the exhibition point (sunbed), the products must be sold only packaged and it is forbidden to prepare them in the area except for drinks such as coffee, juices, etc. It is forbidden to broadcast music and organize events that cause consumer gathering. It is forbidden for customers to use the bars for their stay. The development of table seats in the operating room of the store is allowed.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Other Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Greece, 2020-07-28
Tuesday said the country should learn to live with face masks, after announcing that the mandatory use of masks will be extended into more closed public places.    “We are going to have to learn to live with the use of masks,” said Nikos Hardalias.    The minister in his weekly briefing on the progress of the pandemic said that as of Wednesday the use of masks will also be required before entering shops, providing goods and services of all kinds, public utility companies, banks, doctors' surgeries, municipality buildings, food retailers, hair salons, and beauty parlours.    Face masks are already obligatory in all public transport, taxis, supermarkets, hospitals, health and diagnostic centres lifts, ships and airplanes and for staff serving customers at restaurants, cafes, and bars.    The fine for not using a mask is 150 Euros ($176).
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Greece at 2020-09-03: Wearing a mask  The following nationwide rules are in place around the use of face masks in Greece:    Mandatory use of a mask on all public transport within Greece, including on ferries;  Mandatory use of a mask at airports and on aeroplanes;  Mandatory use of masks in all public indoor spaces, including medical and healthcare facilities, lifts, staircases and any enclosed venue providing goods or services (including supermarkets, grocery stores, bakeries, cafes, banks, government and utility providers’ offices, retail shops, barber shops, hairdressers and beauty parlours and places of worship);  Mandatory use of a mask in high-security areas within camps, social and care facilities and accommodation for refugees and migrants;  Recommendation for general use of masks for a week by travellers to Greece from areas with high coronavirus rates;  Recommendation for the use of a mask in all enclosed spaces and in outdoor gatherings where normal social distancing cannot be observed.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The government of Greece, on 16th September, 2020, announced the following restrictions for businesses in Attica and Athens: Indoor venues with live music will not be operating, wearing masks will be mandatory in all indoors work areas, offices etc., cinemas and theatres will be operating at 60% capacity and wearing masks at all times is compulsory, the number of people who can sit together at a restaurant table will now be limited to 6 people and the number of people attending events and social gatherings is still limited to 50. These restrictions are enforced intiially for a period of 14 days.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside All or unspecified businesses
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
The General Secretariat for Civil Protection of Greece on Tuesday, 15th September, 2020, announced that the following restrictions have been announced for the city of Trikala, which will run for a period of 14 days from September 16 until September 30. 
– All restaurants and bars will be closed from midnight until 7 am.

– All public and social events and gatherings will have a 50-person cap, with the exception of activities in establishments where special rules already apply such as restaurants, theaters and cinemas

description: Greece at 2020-09-18: The following nationwide rules are in place around the use of face masks in Greece:    Mandatory use of a mask on all public transport within Greece, including on ferries;  Mandatory use of a mask at airports and on aeroplanes;  Mandatory use of masks in all public indoor spaces, including medical and healthcare facilities, lifts, staircases and any enclosed venue providing goods or services (including supermarkets, grocery stores, bakeries, cafes, banks, government and utility providers’ offices, retail shops, barber shops, hairdressers and beauty parlours and places of worship);  Mandatory use of a mask in high-security areas within camps, social and care facilities and accommodation for refugees and migrants;  Recommendation for general use of masks for a week by travellers to Greece from areas with high coronavirus rates;  Recommendation for the use of a mask in all enclosed spaces and in outdoor gatherings where normal social distancing cannot be observed.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Greece at 2020-10-01: Health and civil protection authorities have put a nursing home in the downtown Athens district of Agios Panteleimonas on strict lockdown following an outbreak of coronavirus infections in the facility.  Under the new rules, no one will be allowed in or out of the facility except staff, with the ban even applying to suppliers, until October 9.  In the meantime, health authorities started transferring the nursing home’s patients to hospitals in the Greek capital that are equipped to deal with coronavirus cases on Thursday morning.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on visiting nursing homes/long term care facilities

description: On October 16, 2020, the government of Greece establishes four-tier PHSM system based on local epidemiology. For Level 1. Readiness, Level 2 Surveillance, and Level 3 Increased Surveillance,  mask is required a  in all indoor workplaces except those working in a private area without the presence of any other person and b  in all outdoor areas, where it is not possible to maintain a distance of one and a half  1.5  meters between individuals. Level 4. Increased Risk, masks required in all indoor and outdoor areas. Regions currently fall into all four levels. 17 The region of Kozani is included in the fourth level.

description: The Ministry of Interior on 7th November, 2020, introduced 3 different sets of working hours in the public sector during the lockdown. There will be three different shifts for employees, namely 7 a.m. to 3 p.m., 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. and 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. The possibility of special purpose leave is being reintroduced for vulnerable groups, but also for those who have children in high school. Office work will be conducted with the observance of at least 1.5 meters between employees and the continuous use of masks in all areas. The measure lasts until the end of lockdown, that is 14th December, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Regulated government working hours (e.g. work from home policies for government workers)

description: Hairdressers reopened for business on Monday, with the option to work extended hours (7 a.m. to 9 p.m.) and with strict health safety rules in place. Restrictions include: The temporary imposition of a house restriction on residents and the 24-hour curfew, with the exception of pet traffic, individually and around the permanent residence (sms code 6) or for health reasons (sms code 1) or for catering purposes (sms 2- and with the exception of the period between 18:00 and 06:00 of the following) or for work purposes only (within the DE Malesina , for services which remain open and with the relevant certificate). description:
"Greece 2021-05-18
Maximum 3 persons permitted to travel in a taxi or a private vehicle (unless all members of the same family).  Cross-regional travel is allowed for mainland Greece and the islands of Lefkada, Evia and Salamina (use of self-tests ahead of travel is strongly recommended but is not mandatory).  Cross-regional travel to the rest of the islands is permitted but only with either:    proof of vaccination and 14 days since second dose (see Demonstrating your COVID-19 vaccination status), or  a negative result from a PCR test carried out up to 72 hours prior to travel; or  a negative result from a rapid test or self-test conducted up to 24 hours before travel; or  documentary proof of having recovered from Covid-19 (at least 2 months since infection, and no more than 9 months)"
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on  private vehicles in public circulation
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
"Greece 2021-05-25
Based on the available scientific data on novel coronavirus SARS-CoV-2, elderly people as   well as individuals of any age with underlying chronic diseases (e.g. chronic respiratory   conditions, malignancies, etc), belong to groups that are in high-risk of developing a severe   condition and complications.  Therefore, people in high risk groups must systematically implement all measures for   preventing the transmission and spread of the novel coronavirus. If you belong to a high-risk   group, you should do the following:  ? Avoid contact with persons who show signs and symptoms of a respiratory infection.  ? Avoid all unnecessary travels, particularly to areas or countries with confirmed virus   spread in the community.  ? Implement hand hygiene and avoid touching your own face with your hands (eyes,   nose, mouth)  ? Adhere to chronic medication regimen (if available) and to your doctors’ advice.  ? Avoid gatherings and events, unless necessary.  ? Contact your doctor immediately in case you develop symptoms of respiratory   infection; seek medical evaluation.  ? Avoid visits to patients in hospitals.  ? Avoid visits to healthcare units without serious reason"
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

Unless all passengers are members of the same family, a maximum of 3 persons are permitted to travel in a taxi or other private vehicle with up to 7 seats, or 4 persons in a private vehicle with up to 9 seats;  Cross-regional travel is allowed for mainland Greece and the islands of Lefkada, Evia and Salamina (use of self-tests ahead of travel is strongly recommended but is not mandatory).  Cross-regional travel to the rest of the islands is permitted but only with either:    proof of vaccination and 14 days since second dose (see Demonstrating your COVID-19 vaccination status), or  a negative result from a PCR test carried out up to 72 hours prior to travel; or  a negative result from a rapid test or self-test conducted up to 24 hours before travel; or  a self-test declaration signed less than 24 hours before travel; or  documentary proof of having recovered from Covid-19 (at least 2 months since infection, and no more than 9 months)  Travel in Greece  Travel within Greece between Regional Units is permitted subject to adherence to public health measures as outlined above. You must wear a mask at all times on all public transport.    If you are travelling via ferry, you will need to complete a health questionnaire and hand it to the ferry operator before boarding. The necessary forms will be provided by the operator: you should contact them directly if you need further information. Temperature checks may also be carried out before boarding.    If you are tr
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
